data.title: Godot Project Manager and Godot Editor crashes on exit
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10
Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When closing the project manager in any way,  including opening a project, the editor crashes.  When opening a project, the console says:
```
unicode error: invalid skip
unicode error: invalid skip
```
^ that about 40x.
continuing...
```
unicode error: invalid skip
unicode error: invalid skip
ERROR: RasterizerSceneGLES3::environment_set_tonemap: Condition ' !env ' is true.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_scene_gles3.cpp:914
ERROR: RasterizerSceneGLES3::environment_set_adjustment: Condition ' !env ' is true.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_scene_gles3.cpp:929
ERROR: RasterizerStorageGLES3::_render_target_allocate: Condition ' status != 0x8CD5 ' is true.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_storage_gles3.cpp:6244
ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL        Type: Performance       ID: 131218      Severity: Medium
Message: Program/shader state performance warning: Vertex shader in program 4 is being recompiled based on GL state.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_gles3.cpp:122
ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL        Type: Performance       ID: 131218      Severity: Medium
Message: Program/shader state performance warning: Vertex shader in program 7 is being recompiled based on GL state.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_gles3.cpp:122
ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL        Type: Performance       ID: 131218      Severity: Medium
Message: Program/shader state performance warning: Vertex shader in program 16 is being recompiled based on GL state.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_gles3.cpp:122
```

Opening another project shows:
```

unicode error: invalid skip
unicode error: invalid skip
```
again about 40x

```

unicode error: invalid skip
unicode error: invalid skip
ERROR: RasterizerSceneGLES3::environment_set_tonemap: Condition ' !env ' is true.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_scene_gles3.cpp:914
ERROR: RasterizerSceneGLES3::environment_set_adjustment: Condition ' !env ' is true.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_scene_gles3.cpp:929
save presets
save presets
```
this project shows "save presets" about 100x.
continuing...
```

save presets
save presets
ERROR: RasterizerStorageGLES3::_render_target_allocate: Condition ' status != 0x8CD5 ' is true.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_storage_gles3.cpp:6244
```
Closing a project in the editor shows this before crashing:
```

running cmdline: "C:/Program Files (x86)/Android/android-sdk/platform-tools/adb.exe" "kill-server"
EditorSettings::_get - Warning, not found: import/pvrtc_texture_tool
EditorSettings::_get - Warning, not found: import/pvrtc_texture_tool
WARNING: ObjectDB::cleanup: ObjectDB Instances still exist!
     At: core\object.cpp:2003
```

In both instances, the console continues to run and everything seems to work fine besides the crashes.

data.title: removed focus style for import dock LineEdit
data.body:
Just removing the border when focussing the line edit. The border makes users think, they could edit it but the line edit is more or less just used as a label. with a background. maybe we should change it to a label and just change the style box to give it a dark background. I don't know.
No focus makes it already much more obvious that it is just a "label".

data.title: macOS export error: Couldn't load game path '.'
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
macOS Sierra 10.12.6 - Godot 3.0 Alpha 1

**Issue description:**
Whenever I export a game to macOS and try to run it, it immediately crashes. This happens both with an export made from Windows and one made from macOS. When I use Terminal to execute the binary itself (under Content/MacOS/), I get the following error: "error: Couldn't load game path '.'".  
I can however execute the .app file if I do so from within the godot project folder. It's only when I move it somewhere outside of that folder that it no longer works.  
I'm using Godot 3.0 Alpha 1 and I'm sure I'm using the right export templates.  


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new, empty Godot project
2. Export the project for macOS with the default settings
3. Move the exported .app file to another folder
4. Try to run the .app file


**Link to minimal example project:**
[Godot_empty.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1200601/Godot_empty.zip)

data.title: Dont call nativescript callbacks if lib is not initialized
Fail to generate MSVS project for VS2017
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 Pro
Godot 3
python2.7
scons 2.5.0

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
trying to build the Godot source with scons -j10 p=windows vsproj=yes
received an error that says, 

"AttributeError: 'SConsEnvironment' object has no attribute 'MSVSProject':
  File "C:\Z_Development\Godot_Source\SConstruct", line 443:
    msvproj = env.MSVSProject(target=['#godot' + env['MSVSPROJECTSUFFIX']],"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16479286/28972194-b3dc189e-78fc-11e7-92ce-54260fc4d45e.png)

In the Scons' User guide, it says that this builder should be included by default.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Using Developer command prompt for VS2017
successfully build the binary with scons p=windows
then build with scons -j10 p=windows vsproj=yes
receive an error.

**I also received errors related to VsDevCmd.bat. But I don't think it relates to my problem.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16479286/28972049-394eb7a8-78fc-11e7-95cc-5bd218fb4146.png)



**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Godot 3.0 iOS ignores button presses
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 3.0 master 4 Aug 2017
iOS 11 Beta 4

**Issue description:**
Buttons in the interface can't be pressed. I first noticed this with the material tester demo, I couldn't tap the buttons to move from one sample object to the next or use the drop down to select a different background image.

Just found out it doesn't work in another test project I have either so seems something isn't implemented correctly yet in the platform code.

I'll have a closer look tomorrow when I have more time.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Place a button within a scene and hook up the pressed signal to a visible action.
Run the project, press the button, nothing happens.

**Link to minimal example project:**
Use material tester demo

data.title: [Suggestion] Allow the ignoring of detected assets, with a .gdignore
data.body: So, while using Godot I've experienced a few annoyances with the import system, notably bloat in the repository due to automatically imported files. For example, I have a folder with documents for my game, and included are images. These images would never be included in the game, but instead in the documentation, and yet Godot automatically imports the images. What I suggest is allowing for a .gitignore-like system, where users can define a pattern, directory, or file they want Godot to overlook.

data.title: Removing a rigidbody and re-adding it to the scene results in errors and the rigidbody disappearing
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux - 211dfa6602cff8605acfd29986dcf33f3c3176cc

**Issue description:**
Whenever I remove a RigidBody (with mode == RigidBody.MODE_RIGID) from a scene, then re-add it to the scene, I get the following errors (spammed repeatedly):

```
Condition 'p_axis.is_normalized() == false' is true
Condition 'determinant() == 0' is true
```

The rigidbody also disappears.

The errors are there for transform validation and I agree that they should be there, but I would expect a rigidbody removed from the tree with a valid transform to re-enter the tree with a valid transform. This wasn't an issue in older versions of godot (early 3.0 and 2.1) and it breaks key functionality in my game.  This feels like a common use of rigidbodies, so I'm guessing I won't be the only one affected.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1) create a scene with a rigidbody in it
2) run the scene
3) remove the rigidbody from the scene
4) wait
5) add the rigidbody back to the scene
6) watch the rigidbody disappear and your debug console explode with error messages

**Link to minimal example project:**
[rigidbody_readd.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1199283/rigidbody_readd.zip)

data.title: [GDNative] fixed a bug with ambiguous include paths
data.body:
fixes #10071. The problem is that the json.h file includes the
local variant.h instead of the "absolute" core/variant.h

data.title: Compile error with MSVC
data.body:
Godot 3.0 fails to compile with MSVC because of its rules for searching include files. Specifically, when compiling __`modules\gdnative\godot\dictionary.cpp`__ you get this error:

> [...]\core/io/json.h(62): error C2079: 'JSON::Token::value' uses undefined class 'Variant'

The problem is that although you'd expect `#include "variant.h"` in __`core/io/json.h`__ to include __`core/variant.h`__, since MSVC doesn't find it right where __`json.h`__ is, it looks for it according to this:

> In the directories of the currently opened include files, in the reverse order in which they were opened. The search begins in the directory of the parent include file and continues upward through the directories of any grandparent include files.

That is, it seems to go up in the include chain until it reaches the directory of the main file being compiled (__`modules/gdnative/godot`__), which happens to contain a __`variant.h`__ file itself, and that is taken.

I'm not sure how to deal with this. Happens at least with MSVC 2017.

@vnen, have you seen this issue? Any ideas on how to fix?

data.title: Have .tscn and similar files be standard TOML?
data.body:
- __Platform:__ All platforms
- __Godot version:__ 3.0 stable (intended)

At the moment, Godot seems to use its own derivative of TOML for nice, human-readable configuration files... but this is not standard. IMO, it would be healthy for Godot to use standards-compliant TOML to allow for easier automation and external reach. I think these are the things still left after you take out readability (both have it) and semantics (also irrelevant).

Also, another thought I had: perhaps schemas could have their extensions prepended to the `.toml` file extension, a la `.tar.gz` or `.pkg.tar.xz` or similar. This would mean the scene schema would become `.scn.toml` rather than `.tscn` (short for "text scene", right?), and `.scn` alone would still unambiguously mean the binary format in use.

I know Godot already supports XML, but as KidsCanCode pointed out earlier on the Discord server it's not exactly VCS-friendly (nor as easy to read)... but right now it seems to be the only option for a "standard" format for project metadata. Moving to standard TOML therefore kills two birds with one stone, making XML less relevant.

data.title: Fix resource docker thumbnail bug
data.body:
**Bug:**

Changing the resource docker from thumbnail mode to list mode, then playing the project causes the scene thumbnail to be loaded.

**Solution:**

Not 100% sure this is the best location for the fix, but _preview_invalidated seemed to update the the icon image of the running scene without accounting for the docker being in list mode.

data.title: builtin_script_template_improvements
data.body:
~~# template~~
~~This adds another script template with a lot of additional information.~~
~~For the lazy users who just want to get a little idea without reading any docs.~~


~~Any thoughts? feel free to propose changes to the template.~~
### loading templates
the pr also changes how templates are loaded.
Before templates only where loaded when there is no script_template folder.
Now they are loaded when one template is missing in the script_template folder.

data.title: Crash in editor when zooming/rotating
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win 7 x64
Godot 2.1.4 beta (both June and August builds)

**Issue description:**
Godot engine crashes when zooming/rotating the editor camera.

The project attached is the exact same project I'm using in 2.1.3 stable so this is a regression.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1) Load the project
2) open a 3d scene (Main.scn or Navigation.tscn), try to move the camera around e.g to see the road bend from up close.
3) Crash (sometimes takes more movements, but generally trying to zoom far out is a nearly sure bet)

Note: I am using modo navigation, pan is shift and zoom is ctrl.

**Link to minimal example project:**
https://www.dropbox.com/s/jb5izxr90i4zfa1/FreeRoamRacer%20-%20Kopia%20beta.zip?dl=0

(Had to dropbox because GH complains about the file being too big)

data.title: Exported variables are reseted to default upon saving
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux, aef974e7a8577f857be8cf89f02844575d0839bb

**Issue description:**
Some types of exported variables seems to be reseted when saving scene. I can tell for sure that's a case for exported int types. (including enum style int hints(int, "Val1", "Val2")).
![exportedintreset](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/28914272-5f7d8c7c-783b-11e7-99aa-1f20d7522e77.gif)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Download sample project
2. Open "res://Issues/ExportedVariablesSaveIssue/ExportedVariablesSaveIssue.tscn"
3. Change values in inspector
4. Save scene with ctrl+s or from File menu.
5. Observe that changes made in exported int values are gone.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[ExportIntResetIssue.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1196633/ExportIntResetIssue.zip)

data.title: Forward frame call to GDNative libraries
data.body:
At the moment there is no way for a GDNative library to do something during frame idle time. To temporarily solve that in [godot-nim](https://pragmagic.github.io/godot-nim/master/index.html) I implemented [NimRuntime](https://github.com/pragmagic/godot-nim/blob/master/godot/nimruntime.nim) class, which is supposed to be added as an AutoLoad singleton. But this approach has drawbacks:

1. It adds burden on the user of adding the class to the project.
2. It doesn't work in the editor. I could also add `NimEditorRuntime` plugin, but this again has issue (1) of burdening end user.

So the library itself becomes not self-contained, since you can't just add it to the project and expect it to work.
A simple solution is to forward frame() call to the library where necessary actions could be performed. It's called during idle time, so it is perfectly fit for this use case.
